awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measurement of Particle Aggregation in Laboratory-scale Flows for Improved Models of Volcanic Ash Fallout and Entrainment
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions produce clouds of ash, which are hazardous to air travel and infrastructure.  In emergencies, forecasters predict the transport of ash using numerical models, but they typically assume that particles fall as individuals to simplify the analysis.  In reality, fine ash particles combine together into larger clusters, accelerating their rate of fall.  This allows the ash to fall out of the cloud.  Rates of aggregation depend on many factors, including moisture, electric charge, and turbulence.  There is limited existing data on the effects of these properties, particularly for turbulent flows, even though aggregation affects up to 95% of fallout in some eruptions.  Hence, there is a need for better experimental measurements of aggregation processes, along with more advanced models that include the phenomenon.

This study aims to improve forecasting of volcanic hazards through both high-accuracy experiments and upgraded models.  Ash aggregation will be examined in two different, relevant flow conditions: homogeneous turbulence and high-speed jets.  High-resolution optical techniques will be used to study the flow, turbulence, and particle clustering.  The results will be integrated into state-of-the-art analytical models, including some used for forecasting.  Further, this research will be presented to the broader public through a series of hands-on demonstrations at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the role of turbulent eddies and liquid water in the aggregation of small particles in volcanic plumes.  Ash particles aggregate in water-rich volcanic plumes, increasing the average size of ash particles so they fall out of suspension more rapidly. Direct measurement inside a real plume is not feasible, so a lab-scale experiment was constructed to replicate the important conditions that control the aggregation process. Particles were coated with liquid water by condensation and suspended in a turbulent flow. Aggregation was measured indirectly by collecting physical samples of the aggregates, and directly using high-speed video recordings. The measurements led to a new semi-empirical model for the sticking efficiency, which relates the water film thickness and collision inertia to the probability that two particles will stick. The sticking efficiency expression was incorporated into a new 1D numerical plume model that calculates important quantities relevant to the aggregation process in volcanic plumes, like turbulence intensity, liquid water concentration, and particle size distribution through the height of the plume. Compared to prior studies that neglect the effects of aggregation, the 1D model offers a substantial improvement in our ability to predict the lifetime of volcanic ash in the atmosphere. The results of this project will have impacts on other modeling efforts in the future. For example, by coupling the present 1D model with an existing 3D ash dispersion code, the effect of aggregation on the 3D ash cloud concentrations and associated hazards can be better understood.
